Randomized trials have compared coronary artery bypass conduit patency, but only through pairwise comparisons.

To investigate angiographic patency rates of all conduits used in coronary bypass surgery.

Systematic literature search for randomized controlled trials comparing angiographic patency rates.
Compared conduits: conventionally harvested saphenous vein, no-touch saphenous vein, radial artery (RA), right internal thoracic artery, gastroepiploic artery.
Primary outcome was graft occlusion. Included 14 studies with 3651 grafts analyzed (weighted mean follow-up: 5.1 years).
Compared to conventionally harvested saphenous vein, RA (IRR 0.54; 95% CI 0.35-0.82) and no-touch saphenous vein (IRR 0.55; 95% CI 0.39-0.78) had significantly lower graft occlusion.
RA ranked as best conduit (score 0.87 vs 0.85 for no-touch saphenous vein, 0.23 for right internal thoracic artery, 0.29 for gastroepiploic artery, 0.25 for conventional saphenous vein).
Conclusion: Only RA and no-touch saphenous vein show significantly lower occlusion rates compared to conventional saphenous vein.

PFO closure plus antiplatelet therapy probably reduces ischemic stroke recurrence compared to antiplatelet alone (RD -87 per 1000 over 5 years, moderate certainty).
PFO closure probably increases risk of persistent atrial fibrillation (RD +18, moderate certainty) and device-related adverse events (RD +36, high certainty).
Anticoagulation may reduce stroke recurrence compared to antiplatelet therapy but probably increases major bleeding risk (RD +12, moderate certainty).

Existing research suggests knowledge flows are geographically localized, often interpreted as evidence of knowledge spillovers or externalities.
There is a gap in understanding the role of inventor mobility and co-invention networks in explaining the observed localization of knowledge diffusion.
To assess the contribution of mobile inventors and their co-invention networks to the diffusion of knowledge across firms and geographical areas (cities/states).
To re-evaluate the common interpretation of localized knowledge flows as pure externalities by accounting for inventor mobility.
To determine the extent to which spatial proximity affects knowledge flows after controlling for inventor mobility and networks.
Uses an original dataset of US inventors' patent applications at the European Patent Office in drugs, biotechnology, and organic chemistry.
Combines the methodology of Jaffe et al. (1993) for measuring localization of knowledge flows (via patent citations) with tools from social network analysis.
Controls for inventor mobility and the resulting co-invention network to isolate the residual effect of spatial proximity.
After controlling for inventor mobility and co-invention networks, the residual effect of spatial proximity on knowledge diffusion is greatly reduced.
The primary reason geography constrains knowledge diffusion is that mobile researchers tend not to relocate far, leading to localized co-invention networks.
This finding challenges common interpretations of localized knowledge flows as externalities, suggesting they are significantly driven by the localization of inventor networks themselves.

Used risk ratios (RRs) and mean difference (MD) for analysis, with surface under the cumulative ranking curve (SUCRA) for ranking treatments
UCG showed highest probability for improving urinary albumin excretion rate (UAER) with MD -47 and SUCRA 98.0%
CXC achieved best overall response rate (ORR) with RR 1.3 and SUCRA 91.9%

44 RCTs included involving 4,345 patients and 9 Chinese patent medicines.

Ranking of efficacy: Dan'e Fukang Plaster+conventional treatment best for reducing VAS scores; Xiaojin Capsules+conventional treatment best for reducing CA125; Gongliuxiao Capsules+conventional treatment best for reducing E2; Guizhi Fuling Capsules+conventional treatment best for reducing recurrence rate.

There is a need to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chinese patent medicines (CPMs) for treating insomnia.
Existing randomized controlled trials (RCTs) on this topic require systematic synthesis and analysis.
To evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chinese patent medicines in the treatment of insomnia using frequency network Meta-analysis.
To rank the optimal medication regimens combining CPMs with nonbenzodiazepine drugs (NBZDs) for different outcomes.
Conducted a systematic review of RCTs from CNKI, Wanfang, VIP, SinoMed, PubMed, EMbase, and Cochrane Library up to October 2020.
Used Cochrane handbook 5.3 bias risk assessment tool to evaluate study quality.
Performed Meta-analysis and Network Meta-analysis using RevMan 5.3 and Stata/MP 15.1 software.
Included 27 RCTs covering 11 kinds of Chinese patent medicines.
CPMs combined with NBZDs showed superior effective rate, PSQI score improvement, and safety compared to NBZDs alone for multiple medicines.

Network Meta-analysis ranked top regimens: for effective rate - NBZDs + Shugan Jieyu Capsules, + Zaoren Anshen Capsules, + Shensong Yangxin Capsules; for PSQI improvement - NBZDs + Yangxue Qingnao Granules, + Tianmeng Liquid, + Yindan Xinnaotong Capsules.

Conclusion: CPMs combined with NBZDs effectively alleviate insomnia symptoms with high safety, but findings require verification with higher-quality studies due to methodological limitations in included RCTs.
